Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and I can feel the tension in the air as customers clutch their last-minute holiday purchases. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “Stay friendly, no matter what.” The woman in front of me slams her items on the counter, her voice sharp as she complains about the wait. I force a smile, trying to keep my tone calm and patient, even as my heart pounds. I glance at the clock—my volunteer shift starts in fifteen minutes, across town. I’m the only one with the keys, and people will be waiting in the cold for me to open up. My phone buzzes with a reminder, and guilt twists in my stomach. I want to help everyone, but I can’t be in two places at once. The customer’s glare brings me back to the present, and I swallow hard, torn between the expectations of my job and my commitment to the people counting on me at the shelter.
